Award.AwardTitle: Role of RNS2 in Ribosome Recycling via Ribophagy

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit. The overall objective of this project is to determine (1) the connection between ribosomal RNA decay and the molecular recycling pathway of autophagy in plants, and (2) the role of the ribonuclease RNS2 in these processes. Ribosomes are essential components of all cells and act as protein synthesis machines that are broken down and replaced at specific rates. The pathways of normal ribosome decay, however, especially that of ribosomal RNA (rRNA) decay, have not been described. Studies in yeast found that cells growing under nitrogen starvation induce a specialized type of autophagy, called ribophagy, which targets ribosomes for degradation to a vacuole for this purpose. Whether this process occurs in plants and is involved in normal rRNA decay are unknown. Preliminary experiments for this project found that RNS2 is required for rRNA degradation under normal growth conditions in Arabidopsis. RNS2 is constitutively expressed, and mutants lacking RNS2 activity accumulate RNA in the vacuole with longer rRNA half-life. These mutants also exhibit constitutive autophagy, which suggests the possible involvement of a ribophagy-related mechanism in ribosome degradation under non-stress conditions. To accomplish the objective of this project, pathways for degradation of ribosomal RNA and proteins will be analyzed using in vivo labeling and microscopy approaches in wild type and rns2 mutant plants. The project will determine the extent to which autophagy is involved in ribosome recycling through generation of double mutants between rns2 and autophagy-related mutants and through use of inhibitors of vacuolar degradation. Further experiments will identify the cellular compartments involved in ribosome decay and will characterize the molecular changes evident in rns2 mutant plants. Completion of this research will reveal the basic cellular apparatus needed for rRNA decay, will provide new knowledge on how plants regulate this process, and will reveal the biological role of the conserved enzymes involved, which so far has remained elusive.

Broader impacts. This project will provide opportunities for undergraduate students, graduate students and postdoctoral trainees to participate in all interdisciplinary areas of this research. In addition to Iowa State University students, an internship program will be established to provide research opportunities for undergraduate students in the biology program at Grand View University, a four-year undergraduate institution that lacks research programs. This internship program will consist of a 9-week summer internship in which 3 students each summer will receive basic training in molecular biology techniques and will participate in the scientific process, from experiment design to data interpretation. Students will also participate in a workshop led by Iowa State and Grand View faculty in which they will engage in formal discussions about current scientific issues that concern society as a whole. The co-PI is participating in the development of a video game, aimed at high school and beginning undergraduate students, in which the player navigates a three-dimensional cellular environment within a plant and completes tasks based on cell functions and biochemical reactions. The research from this project will be incorporated into the game play as a strategy to demonstrate concepts of recycling of cellular components. As well as developing an educational tool that will be valuable for a wide range of audiences, this project also will provide the high school and undergraduate students involved in its development with extensive experience in a highly interdisciplinary research project that requiries the integration of research, programming design, and educational training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ribosomes are some of the most complex, abundant, and essential cellular machines that exist in all organisms. Synthesis of ribosomes entails a large resource commitment for cells, yet the mechanisms for recycling their components once their biological function is completed has not been studied in detail.

One of the main constituents of ribosomes is ribosomal RNA (rRNA). We had previously identified a vacuolar member of the Arabidopsis thaliana Ribonuclease T2 family, RNS2, which was required for ribosomal RNA degradation under normal growth conditions. We also had found evidence suggesting that autophagy (the cellular process of “self-eating”) could be involved in rRNA decay. The overall objective of this proposal was to determine the connection between rRNA decay and autophagy in plants, and the role of RNS2 in these processes. For this purpose, we used a combination of biochemical, microscopy and genetic approaches.

Our work confirmed that RNS2 is essential for normal rRNA degradation, and identified several novel mechanisms that can transport rRNA from the cytoplasm, the location for its biological function, to the vacuole where RNS2 can process it. A potentially selective mechanism uses part of the autophagy machinery to transport RNA into the vacuole under normal conditions. A second mechanism independent of the autophagy machinery can also transport RNA to the vacuole consuming energy (ATP) with the help of ancillary vacuolar proteins. When this process is disrupted, for example by mutations that eliminate RNS2 activity, RNA accumulate in the cells and general autophagy is activated as a compensatory mechanism. This indicates that rRNA degradation is essential to maintain the metabolic equilibrium (homeostasis) of the cell.

To understand why rRNA recycling is necessary, we performed a comparative analysis of gene expression and metabolite levels in normal and rns2 mutant plants. We found that lack of rRNA decay leads to changes in primary metabolism in the cell. Carbon flux is redirected in the mutant towards production of nucleosides, the main constituent of RNA but also used for a myriad of other functions in the cell, which under normal conditions is mainly obtained from RNA recycling. This change in carbon utilization has consequences in primary metabolism and also affects other processes such as cell wall strength and cell elongation that result in the plant’s morphological changes. These analyses also allowed us to identify reactive oxygen species as the likely signal that control the induction of autophagy in the rns2 mutant.

These results represent a significant advance in our understanding of the metabolism of rRNA, an essential cellular component in all organisms, and the most abundant class of RNA in the cell, and its connection to primary metabolism and contribution to maintenance of cellular homeostasis. The RNase T2 family of ribonucleases is conserved in all eukaryotes, and there is evidence that their role in rRNA turnover and maintenance of cellular homeostasis is conserved in most eukaryotes, from yeast to plants and animals. Thus, understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying these processes can have an impact on diverse fields from human health, as an RNaseT2 has been implicated in several diseases, to agronomy, where cellular energy fluxes are important to determine yield and composition of plant products.

Our project also had a significant educational component. We built the research, communication, and mentoring skills of several graduate students and postdocs to help them advance in their own career paths. We also provided many undergraduate students the opportunity to participate in research and communicate their results to the scientific community, including students from community college and small liberal art colleges that had no access to research...
